w:r.w:t: In this lesson, you are teaching the student how to identify and describe the routine that makes up their typical day. In many cases, this would mean getting ready in the morning, going to school, playing in the afternoon, and
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for common routines
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use both sets of words in complete sentences
Today, wake up, brush, take, learn, eat, play, walk, sleep, listen, write
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: Today, we are going to be learning
Go to school, wake up, brush my teeth, play with friends, learn in school, eat with my family, walk my dog
Ask student to identify as many of the daily routines
Explain the concept of “daily” by circling or highlighting “today”
Accept partial answers (i.e. “eating” instead of “eating a meal”)
Complete the sentence frame with the words “wake up”
Visual cue: use image on ppt to explain waking up in the morning
Student should spell, pronounce, and write the words and the phrase
Interactive cue: pretend to sleep and wake up to demonstrate this concept
Ask questions like, “When do we wake up?” or “Do we wake up at night or during the day/morning?”
Pronounce each word on the slide
If necessary, prompt student by sounding out individual words
Ask “does this word rhyme with ‘make’? Yes or no?”
Complete the sentence frame with the word “
Visual cue: use image on ppt to explain
Student should spell, pronounce, and write the words and the phrase
Extension: “What else do we brush? Do we brush our hair?” Use TPR to demonstrate
Complete the sentence frame with the word “
?” *while underlining the picture on the ppt*
food to eat? (only if they demonstrate comprehension of the previous questions)
If you have a dog/pet or stuffed animal pet, you could consider using them as visual props. It would also be helpful if you had dog food available to demonstrate feeding your pet.
With prompts, students should circle the animals that are pets and X out the animals that aren’t
With prompts, student should say the name of each animal
Students will have seen these animals in Track 1
Teach the names of each of the animals
Complete the sentence frame with the word “
TPR: Open a book and pretend to read, show a picture of a school or a picture of students on a rug with a teacher
Ask students what they learn in school, and encourage a full-sentence response
Complete the sentence frame with the word “
Students will have seen the word “listen” in Lesson 2
Model “listen” by cupping a hand to your ear
Use TPR for each image to prompt the appropriate response
Students will have seen these words in Lesson 2
Complete the sentence frame with the word
Ask students if they participate in a sport
Complete the sentence frame with the word
You can ask the student what they like to do after school.
“After school, I like to play, read, bike, practice sports, music…”
Use TPR for each image to prompt the appropriate response
Complete the sentence frame with the word
Extension: Ask students to circle/identify members of the family
Complete the sentence frame with the word
Show picture of pajamas and talk about getting ready to sleep
“What do you do to get ready to sleep?”
“I brush my teeth and put on my pajamas.”
Say each sight word and/or associated phrase
Prompt with TPR as necessary for each sight word
Say each sight word and/or associated phrase
Prompt students with descriptions of the pictures: My family, my pet, my teacher
Freeform “Show and Tell” Conversation Activity Slide
Brief conversation about things that happen in student’s day
“I play sports, I eat with my family, I go to school, etc.”
Ask simple questions about school, play, family-time, or other things today
It would help if you kept questions small
Ask about things that they like to do or don’t like to do
Today, wake up, brush, take, learn, eat, play, walk, sleep, listen, write
Ask students to point out and spell the words on this slide
, and if you still have time, you can ask them to put each of these words in a sentence.
